prior_works.title: Gaussian-Process Factor Analysis for Low-Dimensional Single-Trial Analysis of Neural Population Activity
prior_works.authors: Byron M. Yu, John P. Cunningham, Gopal Santhanam, Stephen I. Ryu, Krishna V. Shenoy, Maneesh Sahani
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced temporally smooth latent trajectories for neural population activity, providing the foundational latent time-course modeling that this paper extends to multi-population settings with directed interactions.

prior_works.title: Group Factor Analysis
prior_works.authors: Arto Klami, Seppo Virtanen, Samuel Kaski
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Developed a factor model where each latent can be active in a subset of groups, directly informing this paper’s key idea of assigning each latent dimension to a specific subset of neuronal populations.

prior_works.title: A Communication Subspace Between Posterior Parietal Cortex and Prefrontal Cortex
prior_works.authors: Jorge F. P. Semedo, Aaron Zandvakili, Adam Kohn, Christian K. Machens, Byron M. Yu
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the notion that inter-areal interactions are mediated by low-dimensional subspaces, which this work generalizes from two areas to multiple populations and multiple concurrent signaling motifs.

prior_works.title: Demixed principal component analysis of neural population data
prior_works.authors: Daniel Kobak, Christian K. Machens, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Pioneered demixing to associate latent axes with interpretable sources, inspiring this paper’s interpretable latents that demix participation across neuronal populations and task-time structure.

prior_works.title: Inferring single-trial neural population dynamics using sequential autoencoders (LFADS)
prior_works.authors: Chethan Pandarinath, Daniel J. O’Shea, Jonathan H. Macke, Surya Ganguli, Krishna V. Shenoy, David Sussillo, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated how to recover smooth single-trial latent dynamics, influencing this work’s focus on characterizing how low-dimensional signals evolve within and across trials.

prior_works.title: Investigating Causal Relations by Econometric Models and Cross-Spectral Methods
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the foundational framework for inferring directionality (causal flow) from time series, which this paper adapts into a low-dimensional, multi-population latent framework for directed signal flow.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core innovation—extracting low-dimensional motifs that specify which neuronal populations participate, the direction of signal flow among them, and how these signals evolve over time—arises at the intersection of three prior lines of work. First, latent trajectory models such as GPFA and LFADS established how to recover smooth single-trial, time-varying population activity. These works underpin the present framework’s ability to capture within- and across-trial temporal structure in a low-dimensional space. Second, interpretability and selective participation across datasets trace to Group Factor Analysis and demixing principles (dPCA). GFA introduced the crucial idea that each latent can be active only in a subset of groups, directly mirrored here by assigning each latent dimension to a specific subset of neuronal populations; dPCA’s demixing ethos further motivates interpretable axes that separate overlapping influences. Third, the concept of low-dimensional interareal coupling from the communication subspace (Semedo et al., 2019) provides the blueprint for studying interactions between populations, which this work scales beyond pairs to multiple populations and concurrent motifs. Finally, the classic notion of directed influence from Granger causality informs how the framework embeds directionality into latent dynamics, yielding an interpretable account of feedforward and feedback signaling. Together, these strands yield a unified, scalable dimensionality-reduction approach that uncovers concurrent, directed signaling motifs across multiple neuronal populations, validated on V1–V2–V3d recordings.
